dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: December 1st, Singles Day is here again. It's the world's biggest online shopping event by a huge margin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: December first, Singles Day is here again. It's the world's biggest online shopping event by a huge margin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinasand the worldsbiggest online shopping event, known as Singles Day, takes place on November 11, with Alibaba and a record number of other Chinese e-commerce companies offering massive discounts over the 24-hour period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it all really took off when JD.com launched that first festival back in 2010. They've re-branded it as 12/1 now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it all really took off when the website launched that first festival back in twenty ten. They've re-branded it as twelve over one now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009; now re-branded as 11/11, the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The numbers are staggering. Last year it raked in over 25 billion dollars in sales.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The numbers are staggering. Last year it raked in over twenty five billion dollars in sales.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world, raking in just over $30 billion in gross merchandise volume last yearand sales are expected to hit $37 billion by that same metric this year, according to Forrester Forecasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Forrester is forecasting it could hit 40 billion this year? That's just... insane growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Forrester is forecasting it could hit forty billion this year? That's just... insane growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The e-commerce festival is expected to be bigger and more international than ever in 2019, with Alibaba increasing the range of items on sale and adding 1 million new products on offer this year, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's interesting, the event is actually expected to be a bit smaller this year, less international. JD.com itself is decreasing the range of items on sale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's interesting, the event is actually expected to be a bit smaller this year, less international. the website itself is decreasing the range of items on sale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The e-commerce festival is expected to be bigger and more international than ever in 2019, with Alibaba increasing the range of items on sale and adding 1 million new products on offer this year, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, they removed like 500,000 products from offer. And fewer U.S. retailers are getting involved—Adobe says almost 10%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they removed like five hundred thousand products from offer. And fewer U.S. retailers are getting involved-Adobe says almost ten percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A larger number of U.S. retailersalmost 25%, according to Adobe, plan to get involved, including big names ranging from Apple to Estee Lauder, posting deals on Alibabas platforms as well as their own U.S. websites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But some big names are still there, like Amazon and Estee Lauder, posting deals on JD's platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But some big names are still there, like Amazon and Estee Lauder, posting deals on J D's platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A larger number of U.S. retailersalmost 25%, according to Adobe, plan to get involved, including big names ranging from Apple to Estee Lauder, posting deals on Alibabas platforms as well as their own U.S. websites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The star power is dialed back too. Beyonce is headlining the opening gala, but that's a step down from previous years, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The star power is dialed back too. Beyonce is headlining the opening gala, but that's a step down from previous years, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba, which kicks off the event by hosting extravagant fashion shows and concerts, is also bringing in more starpower: Taylor Swift is set to perform as the headliner in the opening gala this year, while Kim Kardashian did a livestream on Tmall to launch her fragrances for the shopping festival.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And according to Sophie Cheng from FutureBrand China, even the social media and video-driven e-commerce push is getting scaled back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And according to Sophie Cheng from FutureBrand China, even the social media and video-driven e-commerce push is getting scaled back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Social media and especially video-driven e-commerce, which has taken off in recent years, is expected to be an even bigger part of the shopping bonanza this year, according to Sophie Cheng, general manager at FutureBrand China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Experience is seen as less important now. Fewer celebrity endorsements, less gamification on the platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Experience is seen as less important now. Fewer celebrity endorsements, less gamification on the platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experience is becoming widely seen as one of the keys to the festivals success, for example through celebrity endorsement and the gamification of the Alibaba platform.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And for the first time, JD.com is running this without its founder, Richard Liu, at the helm. He stepped down as chairman in August.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And for the first time, the website is running this without its founder, Richard Liu, at the helm. He stepped down as chairman in August.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2019 will be Alibabas first year organizing 11/11 without founder Jack Ma at the helm, after Chinas richest man stepped down from his position as chairman in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Daniel Zhang called it the Super Bowl for brands. A chance to really wow Chinese consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Daniel Zhang called it the Super Bowl for brands. A chance to really wow Chinese consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Think of 11/11 as the SuperBowl for brands, Jiang Fan, president of Alibabas Taobao and Tmall businesses, told CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But there's a potential boycott to watch. Almost 20% of Chinese shoppers said they plan to boycott American goods because of the trade war.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But there's a potential boycott to watch. Almost twenty percent of Chinese shoppers said they plan to boycott American goods because of the trade war.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Almost 80% of Chinese shoppers said that they plan to boycott American goods during Singles Day, according to a recent survey from AlixPartners, which predicts the U.S.-China trade war taking a toll on participating U.S. brands this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That could really take a toll on U.S. brands participating this year. It adds a whole other layer to the event.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That could really take a toll on U.S. brands participating this year. It adds a whole other layer to the event.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Almost 80% of Chinese shoppers said that they plan to boycott American goods during Singles Day, according to a recent survey from AlixPartners, which predicts the U.S.-China trade war taking a toll on participating U.S. brands this year.

artist_script:
Cold, late autumn in Beijing, the digital shopping frenzy begins.
HostA: December 1st, Singles Day is here again. It's the world's biggest online shopping event by a huge margin.
HostB: Yeah, and it all really took off when JD.com launched that first festival back in 2010. They've re-branded it as 12/1 now.
HostA: The numbers are staggering. Last year it raked in over 25 billion dollars in sales.
HostB: And Forrester is forecasting it could hit 40 billion this year? That's just... insane growth.
HostA: But it's interesting, the event is actually expected to be a bit smaller this year, less international. JD.com itself is decreasing the range of items on sale.
HostB: Right, they removed like 500,000 products from offer. And fewer U.S. retailers are getting involved—Adobe says almost 10%.
HostA: But some big names are still there, like Amazon and Estee Lauder, posting deals on JD's platforms.
HostB: The star power is dialed back too. Beyonce is headlining the opening gala, but that's a step down from previous years, you know?
HostA: And according to Sophie Cheng from FutureBrand China, even the social media and video-driven e-commerce push is getting scaled back.
HostB: Experience is seen as less important now. Fewer celebrity endorsements, less gamification on the platforms.
HostA: And for the first time, JD.com is running this without its founder, Richard Liu, at the helm. He stepped down as chairman in August.
HostB: Daniel Zhang called it the Super Bowl for brands. A chance to really wow Chinese consumers.
HostA: But there's a potential boycott to watch. Almost 20% of Chinese shoppers said they plan to boycott American goods because of the trade war.
HostB: That could really take a toll on U.S. brands participating this year. It adds a whole other layer to the event.
